Yaacova

These two holidays are very different, and they are celebrated differently. Isn't Easter the rebirth of Jesus and Christmas when Jesus was really born? Aren't they eqaually important? Why aren't they celebrated that way?

post_info.post_title: Easter or Christmas, which is more important?

zachvac
I'm not sure but I don't think Christmass was really the exact date of Jesus' birthday.
AlokaParyetra
In many spanish speaking catholic countries, Easter is marked as the most important day of the year. Christmas comes in second.
Yaacova
ok.....but why isn't Easter celebrated like it's the most important ?
thebootfitter

ok.....but why isn't Easter celebrated like it's the most important ?

 I cannot speak for other Christian denominations, but within the Roman Catholic church, it is celebrated as the most important.
Alan Ryan

Easter commemorates the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Of all the miracles that Jesus is supposed to have performed, bringing himself back from the dead is the most significant - and as such, it is the symbolic cornerstone of Christian doctrine. 
 
 On this basis, the Easter event, story, myth - or whatever you choose to call it - is the most important occasion in the Christian calendar.
Kaill

Both traditions are pagan in root.
 
 Christmas (to any biblical scholar worth his/her salt, not the actual birthday of Christ) takes place around the changing of the seasons because people were already celebrating THAT before magical super-beings like Jesus showed up in ancient folklore. The virgin birth story itself can be found in Babylonian and Zoroastrian mythologies (both pre-dating Christianity)
 
 Easter was originally known as "Ester", a celebrating of the Goddess of the same name. Like Christmas, it was a celebrated in recognition of the seasons changing. Spring - Beginnings. This is why symbols of fertility are used to illustrate the holiday: Rabbits & eggs.
 
 Celebrating the changing of the seasons makes some sense to me. Certainly more than does celebrating bizarre notions of an invisible creator of everything impregnating a middle eastern woman thousands of years ago, and an undead zombie saviour flying through the air.
 
 Happy Easter!
 
 Walk into the light...
 emoticon_idea emoticon_xchicken
jitobear

Christmas is a stolen pagan holiday that has become an over-priced secular nightmare.
 
 Easter traditions have some pagan roots as well, however it is also the anniversary of Christ's death which is critical to Christian faith.
 
 The only thing we were asked to remember however, is the last supper - the eucharist.
Alan Ryan

It's true that Christmas and Easter are traditions which have pagan roots: but this doesn't signify as far as Christians are concerned since they would cite the New Testament as the authority for their celebration of these "feasts" and would piously reject their pagan associations (or "contamination").
